extracted_data.point: Vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is possible in 60–85% of cases, but success depends on the reason for the prior cesarean, current fetus size, and maternal weight.
rationale: Vaginal birth is possible in 60–85% of cases after a previous cesarean section.
The likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after a previous cesarean depends on the reason for the prior cesarean, the size of the current fetus, and the mother's weight.

extracted_data.point: A successful vaginal birth after cesarean is associated with shorter recovery and reduced risk of complications in future pregnancies.
rationale: A successful vaginal birth after cesarean is associated with a shorter recovery period.
A successful vaginal birth after cesarean reduces the risk of complications in future pregnancies.

extracted_data.point: Labor induction after a previous cesarean is contraindicated and should not use prostaglandins (e.g., misoprostol or dinoprostone), due to increased risk of uterine rupture.
rationale: A birth induction after a previous cesarean is contraindicated if misoprostol (a prostaglandin) is used.
Prostaglandin preparations (e.g., misoprostol, dinoprostone) are used to shorten the cervix and induce labor.
Prostaglandins are contraindicated for use after a previous cesarean.
After a previous cesarean, the risk of uterine rupture increases during labor.
Uterine rupture after a previous cesarean can lead to emergency C-section.
Uterine rupture may result in maternal or fetal death.

extracted_data.point: Labor induction after a previous cesarean is only recommended if the patient is medically stable and there are no contraindications, and must be conducted in a hospital with continuous monitoring.
rationale: A birth induction after a previous cesarean must be conducted in a hospital setting with continuous monitoring.
A birth induction after a previous cesarean is only recommended if the patient has no contraindications and is medically stable.
The decision for birth induction is based on a careful risk-benefit analysis for both mother and baby.

extracted_data.point: Induction of labor is recommended after 34 weeks if the amniotic sac has ruptured and labor has not started within 24 hours.
rationale: A birth induction is recommended after 34 weeks of gestation if the amniotic sac has ruptured and labor has not started within 24 hours.

extracted_data.point: Induction of labor is generally recommended after 41 weeks of gestation, and considered urgent after 42 weeks.
rationale: A birth induction is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation as a general recommendation.
A birth induction is considered urgent after 42 weeks of gestation.

extracted_data.point: Labor induction may be considered at 40 weeks if the patient strongly desires it or if there are medical reasons (e.g., severe urinary retention, symphysis pubis relaxation) that make prolonged pregnancy difficult.
rationale: A birth induction may be considered at 40 weeks if the patient strongly desires it or if there are medical reasons (e.g., severe urinary retention, symphysis pubis relaxation) that make prolonged pregnancy difficult.

extracted_data.point: After amniotic sac rupture, the protective barrier around the fetus is no longer intact, increasing the risk of infection spreading from mother to fetus.
rationale: After amniotic sac rupture, the protective barrier around the fetus is no longer intact.
After amniotic sac rupture, the risk of infection spreading from mother to fetus increases.

extracted_data.point: After amniotic sac rupture, the newborn may require antibiotic treatment after birth, and in rare cases may require intensive care including mechanical ventilation due to infection.
rationale: After amniotic sac rupture, the newborn may require antibiotic treatment after birth.
In rare cases, a newborn may require intensive care, including mechanical ventilation, due to infection.

extracted_data.point: Maternal infection of the uterine cavity after amniotic sac rupture may cause abdominal pain, increased bleeding, and fever, and may require antibiotic treatment.
rationale: After amniotic sac rupture, maternal infection of the uterine cavity can cause abdominal pain, increased bleeding, and fever.
Maternal infection of the uterine cavity may require antibiotic treatment.

extracted_data.point: Maternal infection may spread to the peritoneal cavity or distant organs (e.g., peritonitis, sepsis), and may lead to permanent infertility if it causes scarring and blockage of fallopian tubes.
rationale: In rare cases, maternal infection can spread to the peritoneal cavity or distant organs (e.g., peritonitis, sepsis).
Maternal infection may lead to permanent infertility if it causes scarring and blockage of fallopian tubes.

extracted_data.point: As gestational age increases beyond 40 weeks, the risk of labor complications increases, and the risk of fetal complications increases with fetal size.
rationale: As gestational age increases beyond 40 weeks, the risk of complications during labor and delivery increases.
In cases of term exceedance, the risk of birth complications increases with fetal size.

extracted_data.point: As the fetus grows, amniotic fluid volume decreases and may become contaminated with fetal waste, increasing the risk of aspiration and respiratory complications (e.g., pneumonia).
rationale: As the fetus grows, the volume of amniotic fluid decreases and may become contaminated with fetal waste.
Contaminated amniotic fluid may enter the fetal airway (aspiration).
Aspiration of contaminated amniotic fluid can lead to respiratory complications, including pneumonia.

extracted_data.point: Fetal size increases the risk of birth injuries (e.g., shoulder or clavicle fractures), umbilical cord compression (leading to fetal hypoxia), and maternal injuries (e.g., perineal tear, vaginal tear) and severe bleeding.
rationale: Larger fetuses increase the risk of birth injuries, such as shoulder or clavicle fractures.
Larger fetuses increase the risk of umbilical cord compression, leading to fetal hypoxia.
Larger fetuses increase the risk of maternal injuries (e.g., perineal tear, vaginal tear) and severe bleeding.

extracted_data.point: If the amniotic sac ruptures and labor does not start within 24 hours, labor must be induced or a C-section performed promptly, especially after 14 days beyond the due date.
rationale: After 14 days or more beyond the due date, the risk of fetal complications increases significantly.
After 14 days or more beyond the due date, risks include neonatal pneumonia, aspiration of contaminated amniotic fluid, and long-term complications such as permanent arm paralysis.
After 14 days or more beyond the due date, the risk of fetal death before delivery increases.
A birth must be induced or a C-section performed promptly if the pregnancy exceeds 14 days beyond due date.

extracted_data.point: Labor induction may be delayed by a few days if the pregnancy is only slightly overdue, but the risk of complications increases gradually over time.
rationale: A birth may be delayed by a few days if the pregnancy is only slightly overdue.
The risk of birth complications increases gradually over time, though such complications remain rare.

extracted_data.point: Amniotomy (rupturing of the amniotic sac) is performed when the cervix is shortened and slightly dilated, and may trigger contractions, especially in women with prior vaginal deliveries.
rationale: Amniotomy (rupturing of the amniotic sac) is performed when the cervix is already shortened and the cervix is slightly dilated.
Amniotomy typically triggers contractions and labor often begins within hours.
Amniotomy is more effective in women who have previously delivered vaginally.

extracted_data.point: A double balloon catheter may be inserted to stimulate labor by stretching the cervix and releasing prostaglandins; however, prolonged use increases the risk of ascending infection, and insertion may cause mild discomfort.
rationale: A double balloon catheter is inserted into the vagina.
The catheter has two small balloons at the end.
The balloons are filled with fluid to keep the catheter in place.
The balloons stretch the cervix, stimulating the body to release its own prostaglandins.
If the first balloon filling is ineffective, the balloons may be refilled after a few hours.
Insertion of swelling rods is rare in obstetrics.
Prolonged retention of the catheter increases the risk of ascending infection.
Insertion of a double balloon catheter may cause mild discomfort.

extracted_data.point: Swelling rods (swelling sticks) may be inserted into the cervix to stimulate labor by stretching it; however, use is rare and may cause mild discomfort or a slight theoretical risk of ascending uterine infection.
rationale: Insertion of swelling rods (swelling sticks) into the cervix is used to stimulate labor.
The rods are inserted into the cervix under visual guidance.
The rods absorb fluid and swell over time, stretching the cervix and stimulating contractions.
The rods may be removed during a vaginal exam, and may be replaced multiple times.
Insertion of swelling rods may cause mild discomfort.
Theoretically, there is a slight increased risk of ascending uterine infection from swelling rods.
There is currently no documented data on the incidence of such infections.

extracted_data.point: Prostaglandin administration (e.g., misoprostol, dinoprostone) may cause side effects including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and cardiovascular issues, and may lead to overstimulation (contraction storm) or rare amniotic fluid embolism.
rationale: Prostaglandin side effects may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and cardiovascular issues.
Overstimulation of contractions (strong, frequent contractions) may occur with prostaglandins.
Overstimulation may lead to excessive contractions (contraction storm), which may require medication to stop.
In rare cases, excessive contractions may cause amniotic fluid embolism (amniotic fluid entering maternal circulation).
Amniotic fluid embolism is a life-threatening emergency.

extracted_data.point: Oxytocin is used when the cervix is already shortened and the pelvis is dilated, and is administered via intravenous infusion; it may be used to support labor progression and is generally better controlled than prostaglandins.
rationale: Oxytocin is used when the cervix is already shortened and the pelvis is dilated.
Oxytocin is used especially if the patient has previously given birth vaginally.
Oxytocin is administered via intravenous infusion to initiate labor.
Oxytocin may be used to support labor progression after other methods have been initiated.
Oxytocin is generally better controlled via infusion than prostaglandins.

extracted_data.point: Oxytocin may cause overstimulation, leading to excessive contractions, fetal hypoxia, and the need for medication to stop contractions.
rationale: Oxytocin may cause overstimulation and excessive contractions.
Oxytocin can lead to fetal hypoxia (oxygen deprivation).
Oxytocin overstimulation may require medication to stop contractions.

extracted_data.point: Rizinus oil (used in labor cocktail) acts as a laxative and may stimulate contractions, but may cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
rationale: Rizinus oil (used in "labor cocktail") acts as a laxative and can stimulate contractions.
Rizinus oil may cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

extracted_data.point: Egg white solution (Eipollösung) is used when the cervix is dilated enough to allow one or two fingers to pass; during the procedure, a finger is inserted to dislodge the amniotic sac, which may stimulate contractions, and may cause mild vaginal bleeding resembling diagnostic bleeding.
rationale: Eipollösung (egg white solution) is used when the cervix is dilated enough to allow one or two fingers to pass through.
During the egg white procedure, a finger is inserted into the cervix and gently moved to dislodge the amniotic sac.
The egg white procedure may stimulate contractions in some women.
After egg white procedure, a small amount of vaginal bleeding may occur.
The bleeding is typically mild and mixed with mucus.
This bleeding resembles "diagnostic bleeding" that often occurs early in labor.

extracted_data.point: A patient who has had a previous cesarean must inform the doctor of any prior uterine surgery (e.g., C-section, myomectomy, hysteroscopy), as a vaginal birth after cesarean carries increased risk of uterine rupture.
rationale: A patient who has had a previous cesarean must inform the doctor if she has had any uterine surgery (e.g., C-section, myomectomy).
After a previous cesarean, the risk of uterine rupture increases during labor.
Uterine rupture may result in maternal or fetal death.
Uterine rupture may require blood transfusion, uterine infection (endometritis), or removal of the uterus (hysterectomy).

extracted_data.point: The patient must be provided with detailed counseling about the pros, cons, risks, and success rates of available birth options (vaginal birth, induction, or C-section) during a dedicated counseling session.
rationale: The patient should be informed in detail about the pros and cons, risks, and success rates of available birth options during a counseling session.

extracted_data.point: The patient must report any signs of labor (contractions, bleeding, pain) to medical staff immediately, and seek medical attention if contractions are severe or occur in short bursts.
rationale: The patient must report any signs of labor (contractions, bleeding, pain) to medical staff immediately.
The patient must report any vaginal bleeding immediately.
The patient must report contractions that are severe or occurring in very short intervals.
The patient must seek medical attention if contractions begin.
The patient must seek medical attention if vaginal bleeding occurs.
The patient must seek medical attention if contractions become very painful or occur in short bursts.

extracted_data.point: In cases of maternal diabetes, labor induction may be considered if the due date is exceeded, especially if insulin is required.
rationale: In cases of maternal diabetes, the fetus may grow excessively or be at risk.
In cases of maternal diabetes, labor induction may be considered if the due date is exceeded, especially if insulin is required.

extracted_data.point: Maternal conditions such as hypertension, liver or kidney dysfunction, fetal growth restriction, or maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility may necessitate early labor induction.
rationale: Maternal hypertension, liver dysfunction, kidney dysfunction, fetal growth restriction, or maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility may necessitate early labor induction.

extracted_data.point: In rare cases, umbilical cord prolapse may occur if the fetal head is not well engaged, requiring emergency C-section.
rationale: In rare cases, umbilical cord prolapse may occur if the fetal head is not well engaged in the pelvis.
If umbilical cord prolapse occurs, an emergency C-section may be required.
